Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow and worried hollander redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2013 07:37PM hollander wrote: I met with the MO today, and I'm officially done with Faslodex and Aromasin. There is only one small spot on the liver, and she considers the cancer "indolent but persistent". The hormonals haven't been totally worthless, since my lung nodules are stable, as is the one bone spot. But they haven't done the job well enough, so they are officially fired. I'll start xeloda at the end of the week. I'm concerned about the SE's, but also looking forward to a treatment that will hopefully have better results and faster ones. And that will work for a good long time. I'm glad I had the weekend to get used to the idea of liver involvement and probable treatment change. It made today's meeting much easier. Looking for a bright spot here.... my hair has been thinning on the faz and aromasin. MO said it will probably start growing back on xeloda :) . I'll be posting over on the xeloda page, but would appreciate any suggestions, advise, etc. that you all might have. I like to be prepared and think I need to shop for some chemo SE remedies this week, but don't know where to start... Thanks for all of your support and encouragement. I couldn't be making this journey without you! Sending hugs and wishes that everyone gets good scan reports and encouraging treatment plans this week.

Posts.Title: Don't even have a title for this crap Chickadee lulubee

Posts.Content: hollander wrote: Good morning, everyone-- I'm having a PET scan tomorrow, and am really concerned. At my monthly appt. on 10/10 for Faslodex and Zometa, my labs came back with tumor markers up to 94 (had been 68 5 weeks before). I was on Faslodex for 5 months before my tumor markers even rose beyond the "normal" range, so seeing them jump that much is a new thing for me. Also, my liver numbers were both elevated, and they've never been anything but normal. I'd been on vacation the week before, and had a few margaritas that I don't normally drink, and I'd taken 2 lortabs for pain the day before my appt., but I don't think any of that should be enough to cause the liver increase. I've been having abdominal area pain, but my last scan 3 months ago didn't show anything but stable lung mets (small nodlues) and a very small area of activity on my pubic bone. My ribs have been feeling sore, and I have occasional pain in my lower back and mid-spine. It's so hard to know what's cancer pain and what's SE's. Advil is usually enough to lessen the pain when I have it. This cancer is supposed to be slow growing, and not aggressive based on the path report back in Feb. But if I have even more bone mets and new liver mets, how can it be slow growing?? Maybe I should ask slow compared to what?!? I asked my MO's nurse if it liver mets, what medication can I expect, and she said they are not even thinking that it's liver mets, so I shouldn't be, either. So I have to wait for the report, and for my MO to return to the office a week from today. I have a almost a whole week to wait. And worry. And all the busy days at work, pretty weather, nice walks, appreciating every day and positive thoughts won't change a thing. As much as try to think positively about long-term planning for everything, news like this (or potential news, at this point) brings those dreams crashing down. I try to keep it real for my family without freaking them out (scan+ new activity= new treatment plan), but my heart just breaks when I think about the long term reality. Unless some new wonderful cure comes along, it feels like each new scan brings news that robs me of time that I thought I would have. My sweet mom always says not to worry about things you can't do anything about, so technically I shouldn't worry until I meet with the MO next Monday. But I just don't have a good feeling about this. All that being said, reading about those of you who've had luck with treatment for assorted mets does reassure me, so thanks for posting on all of those threads. You give hope when it's hard to find anywhere else!! And thanks for sending prayers my way-- I need as many as I can get!!! Life may not be the party we hoped for, but while we're here we should dance! Dx 2/2007, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/13/2007 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Free TRAM flap; Reconstruction (right): Free TRAM flap Chemotherapy 4/19/2007 CEF Chemotherapy 6/21/2007 Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 9/12/2007 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Hormonal Therapy 10/20/2007 Femara (letrozole) Surgery 6/3/2009 Reconstruction (left) Dx 2/2013, ILC, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 2/21/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Hormonal Therapy 7/11/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Chemotherapy 10/31/2013 Xeloda (capecitabine) Dx 3/2/2015, ILC, Stage IV, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 3/5/2015 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 11/15/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Radiation Therapy 5/31/2016 External: Brain Radiation Therapy 6/1/2016 External: Bone Chemotherapy 6/16/2016 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow and worried hollander redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2013 02:30AM hollander wrote: I didn't have to wait for my appointment on Monday to get my PET scan results after all. I spoke with my MO's PA late yesterday. Results are a good news (in my mind, anyway), bad news combination. Good news first. My lung nodules are inactive, and didn't light up at all. No new bone activity, and the one area that showed up last time hadn't changed. Apparently the pain I've had in my side has been caused by a fractured rib that I didn't know I had. Who knows how that happened-- haven't fallen, haven't had a bad cough. The PA emphasized that there was no cancer in my ribs. I had a normal bone density test in August, before I started Aromasin, so who knows. Can't do anything for it anyway, and the pain isn't constant. So it seems that the the weird wandering aches and pains I've been having are either SE related or just aging related. I can deal with that. But now I wonder if a PET scan is the best for showing bone mets? The bad news... I have a new spot on my liver, approx, 1 cm by 2 cm. The PA was really surprised. Even though my liver numbers were up some on my blood work, she wasn't expecting to find a met there. But my tumor marker was up, too, and the liver activity does explain that. She thinks the MO may want to biopsy it to see where it came from, since I've been on anti-hormonals. I asked her what the next treatment might be, and she said depending on the liver biopsy, it could be xeloda. Yikes. I've been in the stage IV club since February, and I hate to think we're already looking at one of the big guns. It seems weird that each scan is showing that treatments are taking care of what has shown up on the previous scan, but there's progression somewhere else. We are really playing whack-a-mole!! I hope whatever treatment comes next will slow this beast down. I feel good right now and haven't had to change my routine-- still work 40+ hours a week, take care of the house and yard, etc. I am worried about how xeloda might change all of this. I would be most grateful for any suggestions or advice any of you who have been down this path might have. I was on Femara for 5 years, so that's not an option. Are there other hormonals that might work, or is a chemo really the next step? I'd love to have some info from your experiences when I have my appt. on Monday morning. Thanks again for all of your kind thoughts and prayers-- they help me know I will get through whatever comes next in this journey.

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2014 08:56PM hollander wrote: Hi Woodylb-- Sorry to hear about your progression.  I just hate this disease!  I'm getting ready to start round 16 of xeloda tomorrow.  I'm on the 14/7 schedule, taking 2000mg per day (that's 2 pills in the am and 2 in the pm).  It brought my tumor marker down from 106 to the mid 50's, and my liver numbers returned to normal.  My MO typically doesn't scan unless symptoms or blood work indicate something fishy going on.  While on xeloda, I did develop a small mass in the pleura of my left lung (where the original mets showed up).  I was having some pain in the rib area, so did a CT.  Did 14 rads, and the pain is gone.  My tumor markers have been slowly creeping up about 10 points a month, but labs haven't been off, so hopefully the rads will take care of that creeping increase.  I'll find out at my next appt. on 3 weeks. I've been lucky with xeloda, knock on wood!!  My main problem has been some hand and foot syndrome, but I moisturize and that helps with the peeling and dryness.  Neutrogena foot cream is great, and I also use Vanicream.  My dermatologist likes coconut oil, but you definitely need to wear socks since it's so greasy.  I've had some occasional abdominal pain (like gas pain, not nausea), and Gas-X usually takes care of that.  I loaded up on side effect remedies before I took the first dose, and haven't needed most of them.  But it helps to know that I have them, just in case.  Be sure to take xeloda with food, or within 30 minutes of eating, and drink a big glass of water when you take it.  I hope I can continue on it since it's been pretty easy for me.  I hope it works well for you, and treats you gently! ILC is such a weird little beasty.  My MO has described mine as "indolent but persistent".  So far, each treatment has taken care of the most recent progression, but has allowed another one to pop up somewhere else.  It really is like playing a game of whack-a-mole!  Let us know how you're doing.  Saying prayers and sending (((hugs))) to you.
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2014 07:22PM hollander wrote: Hi Woodylb-  You are so right about ILC being weird.  It does seem to just pop up unexpectedly, with or without obvious symptoms.  Since I was diagnosed with stage iv in Feb. 2013, I've learned to expect almost anything with each scan.  I'm not being negative, just preparing myself for the fact that almost anything can happen.  At any time. Unfortunately.  As fas as weight gain, I've gained about 10 lbs. since 2/13, and it's been more a case of the "creeping pudge".  Some of it may be meds related, some may be ice cream related :).  I know it's not alcohol related, since I rarely have a drink.  I miss it some, but like to think that I'm helping my liver out. Time to relax after a weekend of family birthday celebrations!!  I hope you and all the other ladies here have a week of easy treatments and SE's.  (((HUGS)))

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2014 06:57PM hollander wrote: Well, Woodylb, I'm having a PET scan tomorrow, too..... hoping for good results for both of us!!  After a year on Xeloda, and slowly rising TM's, I'm afraid I might get news of progression and change in tx.  Xeloda has worked well for me, and I've had normal blood work, for the most part, so who knows.  H&F has gotten worse this cycle, and I've had migrating pain in ribs, my right and left sides.  The good news about scans is we will hopefully get clear results.  The bad news?  We might not like what those results are!  Such is life with stage iv. Looking forward to parents' weekend with my daughter this weekend- big football game, tailgate fun, and time with my DD and her friends.  It should be a good distraction as I wait for results, which always take a few looooooooong days.  Sending (((hugs))) to all of you!

Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow and worried hollander redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 08:01PM hollander wrote: Hi Woodylb--  Sorry you have joined our stage iv club, but the ladies here are sooo helpful and supportive, and they "get it" better than anyone else I know (besides my friends who are also stage 4).  Your recurrence of ILC is considered metastatic breast cancer, since it showed up in a "distant" area beyond the breast.   I have occasional abdominal and rib area pain.  My MO reminds me that all of those little pains are not all cancer, and that even if every bit of cancer could be eliminated from my body, there could/would be residual damage that could cause aches and pains from the cancer.  Luckily I've had very little pain to deal with , and there are plenty of pain meds available if needed.  Good luck with the chemo- I hope you get quick and positive results!
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 07:09PM hollander wrote: Hi ladies--  I've had some of that same pain, too!  It's not constant, but it is annoying when I have it.  Usually advil will handle it, if I even need that, but I've had to take a hydrocodone a time or two.  I asked my MO about it, and she thinks it's most likely a xeloda side effect, as opposed to new mets, or the xeloda working on the cancer.  I sure hope that's it.  She said she would be more concerned if it was pain that was constant and would not go away or lessen. My liver numbers were finally back in the normal range at last month's appt.  I should get my results from Thursday's labs tomorrow.  Fingers crossed that everything is still normal, and TM's are closer to normal.  I hope your MO and PCP can give you some good news!

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 10:53PM hollander wrote: Jean, I'm sorry to hear about your new mets.  I don't have any experience with mets in the peritoneum, but hope the Halaven will work quickly and will treat you gently.  Did you have any symptoms with the new mets, besides the rising TM's?  I think one of the biggest frustrations with this disease is that one treatment will work on some existing mets, but will allow others to pop up in another area.  Wish they would hurry up and find that magic bullet that would just wipe out all of those cancer cells!  Good luck with the Halaven.  Sending hugs!!
